Countries_by_Military_expenditures_%28%25_of_GDP%29_in_2014_v2.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Countries_by_Military_expenditures_\(%25_of_GDP\)_in_2014_v2.svg)

Countries by military expenditures (% of their GDP) in 2014, based on data
from the World Bank

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2014_militrary_expenditures_absolute.svg/350px-2014_militrary_expenditures_absolute.svg.png)](/wiki/File:2014_militrary_expenditures_absolute.svg)

[](/wiki/File:2014_militrary_expenditures_absolute.svg "Enlarge")

Countries by military expenditures (absolute) in 2014, based on data from the
World Bank

This article is a **list of countries by military expenditure** in a given
year. [Military expenditure](/wiki/Military_budget "Military budget") figures
are presented in [United States dollars](/wiki/United_States_dollar "United
States dollar") based on either constant or current exchange rates.[1] These
results can vary greatly from one year to another based on fluctuations in the
[exchange rates](/wiki/Exchange_rate "Exchange rate") of each country's
currency. Such fluctuations may change a country's ranking from one year to
the next.

The first list is based on the [Stockholm International Peace Research
Institute](/wiki/Stockholm_International_Peace_Research_Institute "Stockholm
International Peace Research Institute") (SIPRI) 2017 Fact Sheet, which
includes a list on the world's top 15 military spenders in 2016, based on
current market exchange rates.[1] The second list is based on the 2016 edition
of "The Military Balance" published by the [International Institute for
Strategic Studies](/wiki/International_Institute_for_Strategic_Studies
"International Institute for Strategic Studies") (IISS) using average market
exchange rates.[2]
